Description: Lapis lazuli cylinder seal; presentation scene; the suppliant goddess and a worshipper in a cap and fringed robe, with hands clasped, face a deified king who wears a flattened head-dress, holds a footed cup and sits on an unpadded stool beneath a star-disc; space for an inscription; feet, footstool and dais are missing; probably ground down from a larger seal or bead; faults in stone.
Bibliographic references: Collon 1986a / Catalogue of the Western Asiatic Seals in the British Museum: Cylinder Seals III: Isin-Larsa and Old Babylonian Periods (36)
Leichty E et al 1988a / Catalogue of the Babylonian Tablets in the British Museum, volume VIII: Tablets from Sippar 3 (p.168)
Acquisition name: From: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
Acquisition notes: Acquired by the British Museum as a result of Budge's second mission to Egypt and Mesopotamia in 1887-1888; the mission was intended to investigate the "leakage" of tablets from sites supposedly guarded on behalf of the British Museum. Further notes on acquisition and bibliographic references relating to acquisition in catalogue introduction pp.xv-xvii.
